DOC.HEAD: Parent Of Jim Walter Corp. Faces Chapter 11 Bankruptcy
DOC.TEXT: Hillsborough Holdings Corp., the parent company of Jim Walter Corp., said today it was prepared to file for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection if its bondholders did not agree to financial restructuring. Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Co. of New York acquired Hillsborough Holdings as part of its $2.4 billion acquisition of Jim Walter last year. The Tampa-based building materials company is currently fighting a $3 billion asbestos-related lawsuit. The proposed bankruptcy move would be the first involving a large company acquired by Kohlberg Kravis, the leader among leveraged buyout firms, and could have an effect on the junk bond market that has financed many takeovers. Hillsborough officials said the bankruptcy filing was expected to be made Dec. 27 if an exchange offer for $624 million worth of the company's bonds were not accepted by at least 80 percent of the company's bondholders. Kohlberg Kravis has apparently failed to persuade a group of Hillsborough's senior bondholders to accept a proposed financial restructuring of the company. ``If the pending exchange offers are not consummated on their current terms and conditions, Hillsborough and certain of its subsidiaries may have no alternative but to file voluntary petitions for reorganization under Chapter 11,'' said David Townsend, Hillsborough Holdings spokesman. If the offer is not accepted, Hillsborough faces the prospect of having to repay its notes in full, which it told bondholders at a meeting Tuesday that it could not do. Hillsborough's financial problems began last summer when it was named in the class-action lawsuit. Because of the suit, Kohlberg Kravis has been unable to sell off Jim Walter's assets. And without the proceeds from the sales, the company cannot meet its upcoming debt payments.
